journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Reinforced Plastics and Composites

title-group.article-title: Transient response of carbon nanotubes with inhomogeneous coating under radial impact loading and magnetic field

article-meta.aff: School of Naval Architecture, Ocean and Civil Engineering (State Key Laboratory of Ocean Engineering), Shanghai Jiaotong University, Shanghai, People’s Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: X Wang, School of Naval Architecture, Ocean and Civil Engineering (State Key Laboratory of Ocean Engineering), Shanghai Jiaotong University, Shanghai 200030, People’s Republic of China. Email: xwang@sjtu.edu.cn

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2013 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: An analytical method is presented to solve magnetoelastic dynamic stress responses and perturbation of the magnetic field vector in carbon nanotubes with inhomogeneous costing subjected to radial internal pressure shock and axial magnetic field. By utilizing finite Hankle transforms and Laplace transforms, the analytical solution for magnetodynamic stress response and perturbation of an axial magnetic field vector in the carbon nanotubes with inhomogeneous coating are obtained. From example calculations both magnetodynamic stress and perturbation of the axial magnetic field vector in carbon nanotubes with inhomogeneous coating are described and discussed.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Carbon nanotubes (CNTs) discovered by Iijima1 have attracted extensive attention and wide studies. It is seen from investigations that CNTs have small structural size, high tension stiffness and strength, good mechanical characteristics, and excellent electronic, magnetic, and optical transport properties. Because of these superior properties, CNTs can be applied in a wide range of engineering areas such as CNTs reinforced composites, nano-devices, nano-switch, nano-sensors, and high-frequency oscillators.2–5

One of common characteristic of CNTs with inhomogeneous coating is used as nano-sensors, which is often subjected to coupled impact loading and magnetic field. So, understanding magnetoelastic dynamic stress responses and perturbation of the magnetic field vector in CNTs with inhomogeneous coating subjected to radial internal pressure shock and axial magnetic field is essential and may give a useful help in engineering applications.

Coppola et al.6 reported that the electrical resistivity of CNTs-reinforced cement matrix composites is variable with the stress conditions under static and dynamic loads, which can be used to evaluate the stress level in reinforced composite structures, to monitor weigh vehicles and traffic flow. Pentaras and Elishakoff7 investigated the dynamic deflections of geometrically different single-walled CNTs are determined subjected to different velocity impacts and for different positions. Ye et al.8 described the absorption properties of electromagnetic waves from multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs)-epoxy composites. Gregory et al. and Slepyan and Maksimenko910 investigated the electromagnetic wave propagation in CNTs and described the discrete relation of wave propagation in CNTs based on molecular dynamics theories. Li and Wang11 investigated the different wave modes coupled of single-walled CNT subjected to longitudinal or transverse magnetic loads. Qin et al.12 made magnetic nanocomposites by embedding modified CNTs into epoxy resins, and reported their investigation on magnetic properties by vibrating sample magnetometer. Based on a multiple-shell model and neglecting the radially and axially relative motion between two walls of MWNTs, Wang et al.13 studied the effect of magnetic field on wave propagation in CNTs.

To author’s knowledge, the magnetoelastic dynamic stress responses and perturbation of the magnetic field vector in CNTs with inhomogeneous coating subjected to radial internal pressure shock and axial magnetic field have not been reported in literatures so far.

In general, the molecular dynamics model (MD),14,15 continuum mechanics method16,17 and experimental methods18,19 are frequently utilized to investigate the mechanical, electric, and magnetic performance of CNTs. MD method is an effective research technique to accurately simulate the physical properties of structures at atomic-scale. However, the MD simulations are only used to calculate the nanosecond range of nanotubes structures due to the limitation by the vibration modes of the atoms to be of the order of femto-seconds (10-15), in which period most of the physical, mechanical, electric, or magnetic events have not even produced.20 On the other hand, directly using the experimental methods to investigate physical properties of CNTs is also difficult due to specimens and difficulties in manipulating the CNTs with nano-scale. Recently, based on continuum mechanics methods, Wang et al.21 investigated the Radial Breathing Modes of CNTs, and the investigation result is in good agreement with simulation results from molecular dynamic (MD)22 and with relative errors less than 5%. These investigations showed that the continuum mechanics model can offer an effective and simple method to solve dynamic problems of CNTs.

In this paper, a laminated structural model is employed to study the magnetoelastic dynamic stress responses and perturbation of the magnetic field vector in CNTs with inhomogeneous coating subjected to radial internal pressure shock and axial magnetic field. Utilizing finite Hankle transforms and Laplace transforms, the analytical solution for magnetodynamic stress response and perturbation of an axial magnetic field vector in the CNTs with inhomogeneous coating are obtained, where the CNTs is considered as orthotropic material property and the coating layer is considered inhomogeneous orthotropic material. From the results obtained, magnetodynamic stress and perturbation of the axial magnetic field vector in CNTs with inhomogeneous coating are described and discussed. The meaningful numerical results in this paper may be used as a reference for the design of nano-sensor, nano-oscillator and actuators, nano-electron technology, and nano-composites absorbing wave.

sec.title: Formulation and solution for transient coupled equations
sec.p:
Based on laminated structural model, effective investigations on the physical properties of CNTs are presented in literatures.23–25 From these ideas, a calculation model for the transient response of CNTs with inhomogeneous coating under the radial impact loading and axial magnetic field is shown in Figure 1(a), where an MWCNT with internal radius a1 and external radius b1 is located at the centre of a coaxial inhomogeneous coating with an internal radius a2 and external radius b2, and a2=b1. The inhomogeneity of coating layer is defined by an exponential law along the radial direction. A cylindrical coordinate system (x,θ,r) is taken, and x expresses the longitudinal direction of CNTs with inhomogeneous coating, θ expresses the circumferential direction, and r expresses the radial direction. The internal radius of CNTs can be expressed as26 (1)a1=a03(m2+n2+mn)2π where (m,n) is the chiral vector of CNTs as shown in Figure 1(b), a0(1.42A∘) is the C-C bond distance. Figure 1.
(a) The calculation model for carbon nanotubes (CNTs) with inhomogeneous coating under a sudden internal impact load p1(t) and axial magnetic field strength Hz. (b) Hexagonal lattice of carbon atoms with different types of chiral vector.

Assuming that CNTs with inhomogeneous coating is put into an initial longitudinal magnetic field vector H¯(0,0,Hz) with the density vectors of electric current J¯, the radial Lorentz force exerted on the CNTs with inhomogeneous coating is expressed as27 (2)fri=μ¯i(J¯×H¯)=μ¯iHz2∂∂r(∂U(r,t)∂r+U(r,t)r) where superscript i=1,2 express, respectively, the CNTs and the inhomogeneous coating layer, μ¯i expresses the magnetic permeability of the ith layer, and U(r,t) expresses the radial displacement of CNTs with inhomogeneous coating.

Based on the governing electrodynamic Maxwell equations and omitting displacement electric currents,27 the perturbation of axial magnetic field vector in CNTs with inhomogeneous coating is written as (3)hzi=-Hz(∂U(r,t)∂r+U(r,t)r)

From the generalized axisymmetrical Hooke’s law for an orthotropic material,28 the transient stress field in CNTs with inhomogeneous coating is expressed as (4)σri=C¯11i∂U(r,t)∂r+C¯12iU(r,t)r,σθi=C¯12i∂U(r,t)∂r+C¯22iU(r,t)r where C¯kli (k,l=1,2) is the material constants of the ith layer.

Here, the material property of CNTs (i=1) is considered as homogeneous orthotropic material, and the corresponding material properties are (5a)C¯kl1=Ckl1,μ¯1=μ1,ρ¯1=ρ1 where ρ¯i is the mass density of the ith.
The inhomogeneous coating layer (i=2) is described by a special law as follows (5b)C¯kl2=β2NCkl2,ρ¯2=β2Nρ2,μ¯2=β2Nμ2,β=r/(b2-a2),(a2≤r≤b2)

In the above formula, Ckl2, ρ2, and μ2 are, respectively, elastic constants, mass density, and magnetic permeability coefficient of homogeneous coating material and N expresses an inhomogeneous exponent of material, which is an arbitrary real number.

From equations (2), (4), and Reference [29], the governing displacement equation of CNTs with inhomogeneity coating in an initial longitudinal magnetic field vector is written as (6)∂2ui∂r2+1r∂ui∂r-Ri21r2ui=1(Vi)2∂2ui∂t2, (i=1,2) where Vi is the phase speed of stress wave. For CNTs layer (i=1), we have (7a)U(r,t)=u1(r,t), a1≤r≤b1 and (7b)R12=C221+μ1Hz2C111+μ1Hz2, V12=C111+μ1Hz2ρ1 For the inhomogeneous coating layer (i=2), we have (8a)U(r,t)=r-Lu2(r,t), a2≤r≤b2 (8b)R22=L2+H2, V22=C112+μ2Hz2ρ2, L=NC112C112+μ2Hz2,H2=C222-NC122+μ2Hz2C112+μ2Hz2

The initial conditions and the corresponding boundary conditions are, respectively, expressed as (9a)U(r,0)=0, ∂U(r,0)∂t=0 (9b)σr1(a1,t)=[C¯111∂U(r,t)∂r+C¯121U(r,t)r]r=a1=p1(t) (9c)σr2(b2,t)=[C¯112∂U(r,t)∂r+C¯122U(r,t)r]r=b2=0
Radial displacement and stress continuity conditions between CNTs and external-coated inhomogeneous coating layer are given by (10a,b)U(b1,t)=U(a2,t) σr1(b1,t)=σr2(a2,t),b1=a2

The general solution to the governing displacement equation (6) may be assumed as (11)ui(r,t)=usi(r,t)+udi(r,t),(i=1,2) where usi(r,t) and udi(r,t) represent, respectively, the quasi-static part and the dynamic part of the solutions to the governing displacement equation (6).

The quasi-static solution usi(r,t) is obtained by solving the following equation (12a) and the corresponding initial conditions (12b). (12a)∂2usi∂r2+1r∂usi∂r-Ri21r2usi=0, (i=1,2) (12b)ui(r,0)=0,∂ui(r,0)∂t=0 Integrating equation (12a) gives (13)usi(r,t)=D1irRi+D2ir-Ri, (i=1,2) where D1i and D2i are the integral constants determined by utilizing the internal and external boundary conditions and the continuity conditions between CNTs and inhomogeneous coating layer.

From equations (12a), (12b), (11), and (6), an inhomogeneous dynamic equation for the dynamic term udi(r,t), the homogeneous boundary conditions and the corresponding initial conditions are, respectively, expressed as (14)∂2udi(r,t)∂r2+1r∂udi(r,t)∂r-Ri2udi(r,t)r =1Vi2[∂2udi(r,t)∂t2+∂2usi(r,t)∂t2] (15a)[C11i∂udi(r,t)∂r+C12iudi(r,t)r]r=ai=0 (15b)[C11i∂udi(r,t)∂r+C12iudi(r,t)r]r=bi=0 (15c)udi(r,0)=0, ∂udi(0,t)∂t=0,(i=1,2)

A finite Hankel transform of udi(r,t) for the variable ris defined as30 (16)u¯di(kji,t)=Hankel[udi(r,t)]=∫aibirudi(r,t)GRi(kjir)dr, (i=1,2) where (16a)GRi(kjir)=JRi(kjir)Yai-YRi(kjir)Jai and kji(i=1,2;j=1,2,3…) represent a series of positive roots for the natural eigen-equation of the ith layer, as follows: (17)YaiJbi-YbiJai=0 and (18)Yai=kjiYRi'(kjiai)+d1iYRi(kjiai),Jai=kjiJRi'(kjiai)+d1iJRi(kjiai)Ybi=kjiYRi'(kjibi)+d2iYRi(kjibi),Jbi=kjiJRi'(kjibi)+d2iJRi(kjibi)d1i=C12i/(aiC11i),d2i=C12i/(biC11i) where JRi(kjir) and YRi(kjir) represent Rith-order Bessel functions of the first and second kinds, respectively.

Then, taking the inverse transform of equation (16) yields30 (19)udi(r,t)=∑j=1u¯di(kji,t)F(kji)GRi(kjir) where (20)Fi(kji)=∫aibir[GRi(kjir)]2dr=2π2(kji)2(Jbi)2{{(d2i)2+(kji)2[1-(Ri/(kjibi))2]}(Jai)2 -{(d1i)2+(kji)2[1-(Ri/(kjiai))2]}(Jbi)2}

Taking the finite Hankel transform (16) to equation (14) and Laplace transform, and utilizing the homogeneous boundary conditions (15a,b) and the corresponding initial conditions (15c), the solution for equation (14) can be given by30 (21)udi(r,t)=∑j=1GRi(kjir)F(kji)[-u¯si(kji,t)+ωji∫0tu¯si(kji,t) ×sinωji(t-τ)dτ]

From equations (21), (13), and (11), the solution for the governing displacement equation (6) of CNT with inhomogeneous coating is expressed as (22)ui(r,t)=D1i[rRi+∑j(FRI1jiGRi(kjir))] +D2i[r-Ri+∑j(FRI2jiGRi(kjir))] where (23)FRI1ji=-Q1icos(ωjit)/Fi(kji),FRI2ji=-Q2icos(ωjit)/Fi(kji)Q1i=Hankel[rRi],Q2i=Hankel[r-Ri]

Substituting equations (22), (7a), and (8a) into equations (4) and (3), exact expressions for the transient stress and the perturbation of the axial magnetic field vector at the ith layer of CNT reinforced composite are, respectively, written as (24a,b)σri(r,t)=D1iΨ1i(r,t)+D2iΨ2i(r,t),σθi(r,t)=D1iΠ1i(r,t)+D2iΠ2i(r,t) (24c)hzi(r,t)=-Hz[D1iΦ1i(r,t)+D2iΦ2i(r,t)] where Ψ1i(r,t), Ψ2i(r,t), Π1i(r,t), Π2i(r,t), Φ1i(r,t), Φ2i(r,t) are the known function, which are not included in this paper for brevity.

In equations (22) and (24a,b,c), there exist 2i undetermined constants D1i and D2i (i=1,2), which are solved by the boundary conditions and the interface continuity conditions of CNTs with inhomogeneous coating.

Utilizing equations (22) and (24a,b), the boundary conditions (9b,c) and the interface continuity conditions (10a,b) are rewritten as (25)D11Ψ11(a1,t)+D21Ψ21(a1,t) =p1(t),D12Ψ12(b2,t)+D22Ψ22(b2,t)=0D11Ψ11(b1,t)+D21Ψ21(b1,t) =D12Ψ12(a2,t)+D22Ψ22(a2,t)D11[b1R1+∑j(FRI1j1GR1(kj1b1))] +D21[b1-R1+∑j(FRI2j1GR1(kj1b1))] =D12[a2R2+∑j(FRI1j2GR2(kj2a2))] +D22[a2-R2+∑j(FRI2j2GR2(kj2a2))]

Equations (25) are used to determined the constants D11, D21, D12, and D22. Thus, the exact expressions of the solution for the transient displacement U(r,t) of CNTs with inhomogeneous coating, the transient stresses σri(r,t), σθi(r,t), and the perturbation of the axial magnetic field vector hzi(r,t) are obtained.

sec.title: Examples and discussions
sec.p: In example calculations, CNTs with inhomogenous coating under radial internal impact pressure p1(t)=-p and axial magnetic field strength Hz is considered. According to an experiment research, the material property of CNTs in a cylindrical coordinate system is written as31 C111=36.5GPa,C121=15GPa,C221=1060GPa,ρ1=2270kg/m3 The basic material property and the inhomogeneous exponent of inhomogenous PZT coating material is, respectively, taken as32 C111=100GPa,C121=77.8GPa,C221=250GPa,ρ1=4350kg/m3,N=0.6 From equation (1), the internal radius of armchair CNTs with (40,40) is given by a1=2.2nm. In all results presented, the dimensionless calculating parameters are, respectively, taken as (26)σr*=σr/p,σθ*=σθ/p, hz*=hz/Hz,R1=(r-a1)/a1,τ=tV1/a1

In order to simply prove the validity of the solution, the CNT with inhomogenous coating for (b1-a1)/a1=10 and (b2-a1)/a1=20 is firstly computed and the corresponding results are, respectively, shown in Figures 2–4, where computing time τ≤10 is taken. When the computing time τ≤10, that is before the wavefront of stress wave arrives at the interface between CNTs and inhomogenous coating layer from the internal boundary of the CNTs, reflected waves have not produced. Figures 2–4 show, respectively, the response histories of radial and circumferential stresses and the perturbation response of magnetic field vector in the CNTs with inhomogeneous composites under a sudden internal impact loading and axial magnetic field strength. It is seen from the curves in the above figures that the features of the compression waves propagating in the CNTs with inhomogeneous coating is clear, where the radial stress σr* at R1=0 equals to -1, satisfying the internal boundary condition. The radial stress at other points as shown in Figure 3 essentially equals zero before the arrival of stress wavefront. A discontinuity at the wavefront and oscillations occur behind the wavefront respond to the sudden internal pressure. Because of the effects of the strong discontinuities, the sign of the circumferential stress at the internal boundary is reversed as compared to that of the static stress as shown in Figure 4. When the propagation of the wavefront is far from some point, the dynamic stress and the perturbation response of magnetic field vector in the CNTs with inhomogeneous composites gradually approach the corresponding static value at the same point when response time is larger and the effect of reflected wave at the interface and external boundary does not occur. Figure 2.
The response histories of the radial stress in carbon nanotubes (CNTs) with inhomogeneous coating under a sudden internal impact load and axial magnetic field strength, where (b1-a1)/a1=10 and (b2-a1)/a1=20.
Figure 3.
The response histories of the circumferential stress in carbon nanotubes (CNTs) with inhomogeneous coating under a sudden internal impact load and axial magnetic field strength, where (b1-a1)/a1=10 and (b2-a1)/a1=20.
Figure 4.
The response histories of the perturbation of magnetic field vector in carbon nanotubes (CNTs) with inhomogeneous coating under a sudden internal impact load and axial magnetic field strength, where (b1-a1)/a1=10 and (b2-a1)/a1=20.

The computing results of the CNTs with inhomogeneous composites for (b1-a1)/a1=1 and (b2-a1)/a1=2 are, respectively, described in Figures 5–8. Due to the small wall thickness, the effect of magnetoelastic wave reflected among the inner wall, interface, and outer wall on the dynamic stresses and perturbation of magnetic field vector in the CNTs with inhomogeneous composites is produced. Except the radial dynamic stress at the internal boundary σr*=-1 at R1=0, the stress and perturbation of magnetic field vector at other points oscillates dramatically around the corresponding static value. The circumferential stress of CNTs at interface is larger than that of inhomogeneous coating layer at the interface because the circumferential stiffness of the CNTs is much larger than that of inhomogeneous coating layer, as shown in Figure 7. Figure 5.
The response histories of the radial stress in carbon nanotubes (CNTs) with inhomogeneous coating under a sudden internal impact load and axial magnetic field strength, where (b1-a1)/a1=1 and (b2-a1)/a1=2.

From Figure 6 it can be seen that the maximum circumferential stress occurs at the internal boundary (R1=0) of CNTs with inhomogeneous coating. This is about 10 times larger than the maximum circumferential stress at the external surface (R1=1) of the CNTs with inhomogeneous coating. It can be seen from Figure 8 that the maximum perturbation value of magnetic field vector at the internal boundary (R1=0) of CNTs with inhomogeneous coating is about 5 times larger than the maximum perturbation value of magnetic field vector at the external surface (R1=1) of the CNTs with inhomogeneous coating. Figure 6.
The response histories of the circumferential stress (R1 = 0.1) in carbon nanotubes (CNTs) with inhomogeneous coating under a sudden internal impact load and axial magnetic field strength, where (b1-a1)/a1=1 and (b2-a1)/a1=2.

caption.p: The response histories of the interface circumferential stress in carbon nanotubes (CNTs) with inhomogeneous coating under a sudden internal impact load and axial magnetic field strength, where (b1-a1)/a1=1 and (b2-a1)/a1=2.

The response histories of the perturbation of magnetic field vector (R1 = 0.1) in carbon nanotubes (CNTs) with inhomogeneous coating under a sudden internal impact load and axial magnetic field strength, where (b1-a1)/a1=1 and (b2-a1)/a1=2.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p:
This paper describes magnetoelastic dynamic stress responses and perturbation of the magnetic field vector in CNTs with inhomogeneous coating subjected to radial internal pressure shock and axial magnetic field. Main conclusions are:
Without considering the effect of magnetoelastic wave reflected, a discontinuity at the wavefront occurs behind the wavefront respond to the sudden internal pressure, where the sign of the circumferential stress and perturbation of the magnetic field vector at the internal boundary is opposite to that of static values.
Due to the small wall thickness of CNTs with inhomogeneous coating, the effect of magnetoelastic wave reflected among the inner wall, interface, and outer wall on the dynamic stresses and perturbation of magnetic field vector in the CNTs with inhomogeneous coating is produced.
Except given boundary values, the stress and perturbation of magnetic field vector at other points oscillates dramatically around the corresponding static value.
The maximum circumferential stress and perturbation of magnetic field vector occur at the internal surface of CNTs with inhomogeneous coating.
The new results in the present work may be used as a useful reference for the application and the design of CNTs with inhomogeneous coating.
